content.text: This is a HE WSI of a CRC case, consisting of lymph nodes or primary tumor section. What is your initial impression of this image?

I see three main pieces of fibrofatty tissue. In the upper left tissue fragment, there is a prominent, well-circumscribed, and densely basophilic (dark purple) nodule that is highly characteristic of a lymph node. This node appears solid and enlarged. The other tissue fragments are predominantly adipose tissue with some blood vessels and require careful screening for additional, smaller lymph nodes.
Are there any places you want to look into further? Give me reasons why you want to look into each region.

I zoomed into this area because it contains the most obvious lymph node on the slide. Its dense, solid, and dark appearance at low magnification is suspicious and requires immediate high-power examination. The primary goal is to assess the cellular architecture and cytology to determine if it is a benign reactive node or if it contains metastatic carcinoma. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found].
This is ROI 1 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this zoomed-in area, I see the architecture of a lymph node. It is composed of densely packed nodules of small, round, dark-staining lymphocytes. The overall architecture appears to be follicular. I do not see any definite nests of atypical epithelial cells, abnormal gland formation, or extensive necrosis that would be characteristic of metastatic adenocarcinoma. My impression is that this is a reactive lymph node, likely showing follicular hyperplasia, and based on this view, it is negative for metastasis.
